elements.content: Three new three-dimensional (3D) porous Zn­(II)-based metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), namely, [Zn4O­(L)2(NMP)2(H2O)]·2NMP·2H2O (1), [Zn­(HL)­(bpe)0.5]·DMF·H2O (2), and [Zn­(HL)­(bipy)0.5]·DMF·H2O (3) [bpe = 1,2-di­(pyridin-4-yl)­ethene, and bipy = 4,4′-bipyridine], were successfully synthesized by 5′-carboxyl-(1,1′-3′,1″-terphenyl)-4,4″-dicarboxylic acid (H3L). Sing-crystal X-ray diffraction shows that complex 1 is a twofolded interpenetrated 3D framework possessing the [Zn4O­(COO)6] secondary building units (SBUs), and complexes 2 and 3 are two 3D isostructural networks with different N-donor ancillary ligands, where the partly deprotonated HL2– ligands are included. Gas adsorption behaviors of 1 to 3 for N2, CH4, and CO2 have been studied in detail at different temperatures, indicating that the high uptake and selectivity for CO2 will make it as potential gas storage and separation materials. Significantly, complexes 2 and 3 also exhibit the good organic dye selection and adsorption capacity, and the Congo red (CR) and methylene blue (MB) can be separated successfully by 2 in a very short time.

Gas adsorption behaviors of 1 to 3 for N2, CH4, and CO2 have been studied in detail at different temperatures, indicating that the high uptake and selectivity for CO2 will make it as potential gas storage and separation materials. Significantly, complexes 2 and 3 also exhibit the good organic dye selection and adsorption capacity, and the Congo red (CR) and methylene blue (MB) can be separated successfully by 2 in a very short time.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have gained tremendous attention in the past two decades because of their potential applications in gas storage and separation, luminescence, catalysis, and so on. As excellent candidates for gas separation and storage, the driving force for gas adsorption in MOFs has been studied and various strategies have been developed to improve their working capacity and selectivity. Thus, to enhance CO2 adsorption capacity and selectivity, the different methods have been explored in the processes of MOFs construction, including control of pore size, adjustment of surface area and pore volume, and functionalization of MOFs by introducing functional groups or generating exposed active atoms mainly based on the secondary building units (SBUs) method which has been proven to effectively improve the thermal stability of MOFs. More recently, porous MOFs have also become popular for the adsorption and separation of organic dye molecules, because the relative sizes of the channels of MOFs can be fine-tuned according to the sizes of different dye molecules, and thus the organic dyes can be captured successfully in the channels. However, it is still a big challenge to separate different dyes with similar sizes by using MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have gained tremendous attention in the past two decades because of their potential applications in gas storage and separation, luminescence, catalysis, and so on. As excellent candidates for gas separation and storage, the driving force for gas adsorption in MOFs has been studied and various strategies have been developed to improve their working capacity and selectivity. Thus, to enhance CO2 adsorption capacity and selectivity, the different methods have been explored in the processes of MOFs construction, including control of pore size, adjustment of surface area and pore volume, and functionalization of MOFs by introducing functional groups or generating exposed active atoms mainly based on the secondary building units (SBUs) method which has been proven to effectively improve the thermal stability of MOFs. More recently, porous MOFs have also become popular for the adsorption and separation of organic dye molecules, because the relative sizes of the channels of MOFs can be fine-tuned according to the sizes of different dye molecules, and thus the organic dyes can be captured successfully in the channels. However, it is still a big challenge to separate different dyes with similar sizes by using MOFs.

elements.content: Based on the above considerations, we intended to prepare some functional MOFs with high CO2 adsorption and excellent separation of organic dye capacity, and therefore, a symmetrical rigid 5′-carboxyl-(1,1′-3′,1″-terphenyl)-4,4″-dicarboxylic acid (H3L) ligand and two different N-donor ancillary ligands [1,2-di­(pyridin-4-yl)­ethene (bpe), and 4,4′-bipyridine (bipy)] are chosen (Scheme S1, Supporting Information) to meet the requirements in this work. Then, three new 3D porous MOFs, [Zn4O­(L)2(NMP)2(H2O)]·2NMP·2H2O (1), [Zn­(HL)­(bpe)0.5]·DMF·H2O (2), and [Zn­(HL)­(bipy)0.5]·DMF·H2O (3), have been yielded successfully. The gas adsorption properties of 1 to 3 have been studied in detail at different temperatures and showed the higher uptake and selectivity for CO2. Complexes 2 and 3 exhibit high adsorption of the Congo red (CR) and methylene blue (MB) in the aqueous solution, and importantly, the CR and MB can be separated successfully by 2 in a very short time.

Then, three new 3D porous MOFs, [Zn4O(L)2(NMP)2(H2O)]⋅2NMP⋅2H2O (1), [Zn(HL)(bpe)0.5]⋅DMF⋅H2O (2), and [Zn(HL)(bipy)0.5]⋅DMF⋅H2O (3), have been yielded successfully. The gas adsorption properties of 1 to 3 have been studied in detail at different temperatures and showed the higher uptake and selectivity for CO2. Complexes 2 and 3 exhibit high adsorption of the Congo red (CR) and methylene blue (MB) in the aqueous solution, and importantly, the CR and MB can be separated successfully by 2 in a very short time.

elements.content: All the reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The H3L ligand was bought from Jinan Camolai Trading Company. Infrared (IR) spectra were acquired with KBr disks in the range of 4000 to 400 cm–1 by BRUKER EQUINOX-55 FT-IR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were conducted on NETZSCH STA 449C thermal analyzer under N2 stream at a heating rate of 5 °C min–1. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were collected on Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu Kα, 1.5418 Å) at room temperature. Gas sorption isotherms were obtained by ASAP 2020 M adsorption equipment. UV–vis adsorption spectra were collected on HITACHI U-3010 spectrophotometer to monitor the exchange progress.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All the reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The H3L ligand was bought from Jinan Camolai Trading Company. Infrared (IR) spectra were acquired with KBr disks in the range of 4000 to 400 cm-1 by BRUKER EQUINOX-55 FT-IR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were conducted on NETZSCH STA 449C thermal analyzer under N2 stream at a heating rate of 5 °C min-1. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were collected on Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu Kα, 1.5418 Å) at room temperature. Gas sorption isotherms were obtained by ASAP 2020 M adsorption equipment. UV-vis adsorption spectra were collected on HITACHI U-3010 spectrophotometer to monitor the exchange progress.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0297 g, 0.1 mmol), H3L (0.0181 g, 0.05 mmol), and NMP/H2O (16.0 mL v/v: 3/1) (NMP = N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and then heated at 145 °C for 72 h. After a gradual cooling procedure to room temperature, the block crystals were obtained in ∼54.0% yield (based on Zn). Anal. Calcd for C62 H65Zn4N4O21: C, 50.87; H, 4.44; N, 3.83. Found: C, 50.53; H, 4.17; N, 3.72%. IR (cm–1, Figure S1): 3438 (m), 2917 (m), 1604 (s), 1509 (s), 1400 (s), 1313 (s), 1108 (s), 858 (w), 781 (s) 744 (m), 543 (m), 472 (s).

elements.content: Suitable single crystals were tested using a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The structures were solved using direct methods and refined using a full-matrix least-squares refinement on F 2 with SHELXL-2014 and olex2. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The solvent molecules in 1 were highly disordered and were removed from the diffraction data by using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON program. The final formula of 1 were determined by single-crystal structures, elemental analysis results and TGA. The relevant crystallographic data are shown in . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1. The CCDC numbers are 1858947–1858949 for complexes 1–3, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Data Collection and Refinement

Suitable single crystals were tested using a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The structures were solved using direct methods and refined using a full-matrix least-squares refinement on F 2 with SHELXL-2014 and olex2. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The solvent molecules in 1 were highly disordered and were removed from the diffraction data by using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON program. The final formula of 1 were determined by single-crystal structures, elemental analysis results and TGA. The relevant crystallographic data are shown in . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1. The CCDC numbers are 1858947-1858949 for complexes 1-3, respectively.

Single-crystal X-ray determination reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic system with P1̅ space group with twofold interpenetrating network. As depicted in , the asymmetric unit contains a Zn4O cluster, two L3– ligands, two coordinated NMP molecules, one coordinated water, two free NMP molecules, and two lattice water molecules. elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure Description of [Zn4O(L)2(NMP)2(H2O)]⋅2NMP⋅2H2O (1)

Single-crystal X-ray determination reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic system with P1̅ space group with twofold interpenetrating network. As depicted in , the asymmetric unit contains a Zn4O cluster, two L3- ligands, two coordinated NMP molecules, one coordinated water, two free NMP molecules, and two lattice water molecules. The Zn-O lengths are in the range 1.922(4)-2.253(12) Å, the O-Zn-O angles are in the range from 56.8° to 167.8°.

elements.content: In complex 1, the three carboxylate groups of the fully deprotonated L3– ligands adopt the bridging bidentate (η2μ2χ2) fashion to connect the Zn­(II) ions (a). Interestingly, like that of MOF-5, a [Zn4O­(COO)6] SBU is formed by six carboxylate groups from six different L3– ligands, two coordinated NMP molecules, and one coordinated water molecule (a); however, the solvent molecules are not included in the SBU of MOF-5. The rigid terphenyl tectons as the spacers link the [Zn4O­(COO)6] SBUs to form a 3D porous framework (b) with 1D channels along a axis with the effective aperture sizes of 13.7 × 14.8 Å2 (b,c). Due to the large voids, the two single 3D networks are further entangled with each other to result in a twofold interpenetrating motif. When the [Zn4O­(COO)6] SBUs are regarded as 6-connected nodes and all L3– ligands act as 3-connected linkers. The whole structure can thus be represented as a (3,6)-c sit network with a symbol of (4·62)2(42·610·83), as shown in d. The calculated void volume is 26.6% of the total crystal volume by using the PLATON program after excluding NMP and H2O molecules.

elements.content: Complexes 2 and 3 are isomorphous with different N-donor ancillary ligands; thus, the crystal structure of 2 is only described for clarity. Complex 2 is a 3D porous framework crystallizing in the monoclinic C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit consists of one independent Zn­(II) ion, one HL2– ligand and half coordinated bpe molecules. Interestingly, the coordination geometry of Zn­(II) ion corresponds to a slightly distorted triangular bipyramid () with three oxygen atoms (O1, O3#2, and O4#2) comprising the equatorial plane, while the other one oxygen atom (O2#1) and nitrogen atom (N1) from coordinated bpe molecules are located at different sides of the plane instead of the usual axial positions. The Zn–O­(N) distances vary from 2.024(3) to 2.226(3) Å and the O–Zn–O­(N) angles are in the range from 60.70(11)° to 161.50(11)°.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Description of [Zn(HL)(bpe)0.5]⋅DMF⋅H2O (2) and [Zn(HL)(bipy)0.5]⋅DMF⋅H2O (3)

Complexes 2 and 3 are isomorphous with different N-donor ancillary ligands; thus, the crystal structure of 2 is only described for clarity. Complex 2 is a 3D porous framework crystallizing in the monoclinic C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit consists of one independent Zn(II) ion, one HL2- ligand and half coordinated bpe molecules. Interestingly, the coordination geometry of Zn(II) ion corresponds to a slightly distorted triangular bipyramid () with three oxygen atoms (O1, O3#2, and O4#2) comprising the equatorial plane, while the other one oxygen atom (O2#1) and nitrogen atom (N1) from coordinated bpe molecules are located at different sides of the plane instead of the usual axial positions. The Zn-O(N) distances vary from 2.024(3) to 2.226(3) Å and the O-Zn-O(N) angles are in the range from 60.70(11)° to 161.50(11)°.

elements.clean_text: 3  Coordination environment of Zn(II) ion in 2. Symmetry codes: #1: x, -y, 0.5+z, #2: 0.5-x, 0.5-y, 3-z, #3: -x, -y, 2-z.

elements.content: In complex 2, the carboxylate groups of the partly deprotonated HL2– ligands adopt two kinds of coordination models: bridging bidentate (η2μ2χ2) and chelating monodentate (η2μ1χ2) fashions with the Zn­(II) ions (b) to form a 2D double-layered network (Figure S2). Then these adjacent 2D layers are further extended via Zn–N bonds of the cooperative bpe ligands resulting into a 3D porous framework with 1D channels along the b axis (a,b). Topologically, the 3D structure of 2 can be simplified as a 3-nodal (3,4)-connected fsc net with a point symbol of (4·6·8)­(4·62·83) (c). By further careful analyses of the two isostructures, it can be found that the distances of neighbor layer-to-layer separation across the bpe ligands (13.413 Å) in 2 are slightly larger than those of 3 with the bipy ligands (11.162 Å), mainly due to the different lengths of the bpe/bipy ligands (Nbpe–Nbpe = 9.365 Å, Nbipy–Nbipy = 7.080 Å) (Figure S13), and thus, the minimum pore dimensions are slightly different, taking into account the van der Waals radius.

Then these adjacent 2D layers are further extended via Zn-N bonds of the cooperative bpe ligands resulting into a 3D porous framework with 1D channels along the b axis (a,b). Topologically, the 3D structure of 2 can be simplified as a 3-nodal (3,4)-connected  fsc  net with a point symbol of (4⋅6⋅8)(4⋅62⋅83) (c). By further careful analyses of the two isostructures, it can be found that the distances of neighbor layer-to-layer separation across the bpe ligands (13.413 Å) in 2 are slightly larger than those of 3 with the bipy ligands (11.162 Å), mainly due to the different lengths of the bpe/bipy ligands (Nbpe-Nbpe = 9.365 Å, Nbipy-Nbipy = 7.080 Å) (Figure S13), and thus, the minimum pore dimensions are slightly different, taking into account the van der Waals radius.

elements.content: PXRD shows that the peak positions of the obtained crystalline samples of complexes 1–3 match well with the ones simulated from the single-crystal data, manifesting the high phase purity of the synthesized samples (Figure S4). The TGA of 1–3 was performed under a N2 atmosphere from 30 to 700 °C (Figure S5), which showed that complex 1 indicated a weight loss of 30.8% in the range of 30–260 °C, ascribed to the release of four NMP molecule and three H2O molecule per formula unit (calcd 31.2%). Complex 2 released one DMF molecule and one H2O molecule between 30 and 308 °C with a weight loss of 15.5% (calcd 15.7%). For 3, it is similar to that of 2, and it lost one lattice water and one DMF molecule from 30 to 306 °C with a weight loss of 15.1% (calcd 15.5%), the major framework then began to collapse.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD) and Thermal Analysis

PXRD shows that the peak positions of the obtained crystalline samples of complexes 1-3 match well with the ones simulated from the single-crystal data, manifesting the high phase purity of the synthesized samples (Figure S4). The TGA of 1-3 was performed under a N2 atmosphere from 30 to 700 °C (Figure S5), which showed that complex 1 indicated a weight loss of 30.8% in the range of 30-260 °C, ascribed to the release of four NMP molecule and three H2O molecule per formula unit (calcd 31.2%). Complex 2 released one DMF molecule and one H2O molecule between 30 and 308 °C with a weight loss of 15.5% (calcd 15.7%). For 3, it is similar to that of 2, and it lost one lattice water and one DMF molecule from 30 to 306 °C with a weight loss of 15.1% (calcd 15.5%), the major framework then began to collapse.

elements.content: To obtain the guest-free phase of 1a–3a, the samples of complexes 1a–3a were soaked in CH3Cl for 3 days, and then heated under vacuum for 6 h (at 160 °C for 1; 2 and 3 at 120 °C) to exclude the guest molecules, which is evidenced by the TGA curves (Figure S5). In order to study the nature of the pores and gas adsorption properties of 1a–3a, the isotherms are measured for N2, CH4, and CO2, respectively. The N2 adsorption isotherms of the activated samples of 1a–3a are measured at 77 K (Figure S6). The reversible N2 sorption experiments of 1a–3a at 77 K all showed the type II adsorption isotherm behaviors, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas are 10.7, 16.5, and 15.4 m2 g–1, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption Behavior

To obtain the guest-free phase of 1a-3a, the samples of complexes 1a-3a were soaked in CH3Cl for 3 days, and then heated under vacuum for 6 h (at 160 °C for 1; 2 and 3 at 120 °C) to exclude the guest molecules, which is evidenced by the TGA curves (Figure S5). In order to study the nature of the pores and gas adsorption properties of 1a-3a, the isotherms are measured for N2, CH4, and CO2, respectively. The N2 adsorption isotherms of the activated samples of 1a-3a are measured at 77 K (Figure S6). The reversible N2 sorption experiments of 1a-3a at 77 K all showed the type II adsorption isotherm behaviors, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas are 10.7, 16.5, and 15.4 m2 g-1, respectively.

elements.content: Moreover, the CO2 sorption properties of the desolvated 1a–3a at three different temperatures (195, 273, and 298 K) were also studied carefully. At 195 K, their CO2 isotherms show almost identical adsorption performance (). The CO2 uptake values are 66.1 cm3 g–1 (12.9 wt %), 70.4 cm3 g–1 (13.9 wt %), and 58.7 cm3 g–1 (11.5 wt %), respectively. However, once the measure temperatures changed to 273 and 298 K, the interesting results were observed (Figure S7). For 1a, the CO2 uptake are 20.2 ccm3 g–1 (3.97 wt %) at 273 K and 11.4 cm3 g–1 (2.24 wt %) at 298 K and 1 bar. For 2a, its CO2 isotherms are close to linear and the CO2 uptake values are 28.1 cm3 g–1 (5.12 wt %) at 273 K and 13.1 cm3 g–1 (2.57 wt %) at 298 K at 1 bar. For 3a, its CO2 isotherms are also type I adsorption isotherms and the CO2 uptake values are 17.7 cm3 g–1 (3.48 wt %) and 13.4 cm3 g–1 (2.63 wt %) at 273 and 298 K, respectively. It is obvious that the final CO2 uptake value of 2a at ambient temperature is comparable with those of 1a and 3a, while the uptake of 2a is relatively higher at 273 K than those of 1a and 3a. This may be, on one hand, attributed to the single network and uncoordinated carboxylate O atoms (inserted into the surface of the pores) relative to 2a, which make the framework highly polar and form stronger affinity with CO2; and on the other hand, it is ascribed to the larger effective free void of 2a (26.6% for 1a, 28.3% for 2a, and 25.1% for 3a). In addition, all of them do not adsorb CH4 well at different temperatures.

elements.content: Adsorption isotherms of 1a (a), 2a (b), and 3a (c) of CO2 and CH4 at 195 K.

elements.content: The selectivities of CO2/CH4 were further characterized. All of them show high adsorption selectivity for CO2/CH4 at 298 K, as shown in . The adsorption selectivities are calculated via the ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) (Figures S8–S10). For the equimolar mixture of 1a–3a, the CO2/CH4 selectivity is estimated as 41.2, 35.7, and 56.6, respectively, which can be compared with the reported MOF materials under similar conditions, such as ZIF-100 (5.9), MOF-177 (4.4), and the hybrid material CNT@Cu3(BTC)2 (5.6). The values are comparable with those high selectivities of MOFs functionalized with the open metal sites or polar groups. The significant CO2 sorption selectivity over CH4 in 1a to 3a can be mainly associated with the differences in the electrostatic interactions between CO2-carboxylate interactions, because of its much larger quadrupole moment (−1.4 × 10–39 Cm2) than that of CH4 (0 Cm2). In addition, the smaller kinetic diameter of CO2 (3.3 Å) than that of CH4 (3.8 Å) and N2 (3.64 Å) enables it to easily enter into the pores. The enthalpies of CO2 adsorption for 2a (47.7 kJ mol–1) are higher than 1a (44.4 kJ mol–1) and 3a (19.1 kJ mol–1) at initial coverage ().

elements.content: Generally, there are mainly three reasons for the adsorption process, i.e., size selectivity, electrostatic attraction, and the ion exchange. Because of existence of the polarized carboxylic groups in complexes 2 and 3, seven kinds of organic dyes with different molecular sizes and electronegativity were selected to be the candidates to study the influence of isomerism on dye adsorption in this work. The complexes 2 and 3 (20 mg) were put into seven kinds of organic dye aqueous solutions with concentration of 20 ppm, Cresol Red (CR), Methylene Green (MG), Malachite Green Oxalate (MGO), Methylene Blue (MB), Alizarin Red (AR), Congo Red (CR), and Methyl Orange (MO), respectively (Figure S11).
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption of Dye Molecules

Generally, there are mainly three reasons for the adsorption process, i.e., size selectivity, electrostatic attraction, and the ion exchange. Because of existence of the polarized carboxylic groups in complexes 2 and 3, seven kinds of organic dyes with different molecular sizes and electronegativity were selected to be the candidates to study the influence of isomerism on dye adsorption in this work. The complexes 2 and 3 (20 mg) were put into seven kinds of organic dye aqueous solutions with concentration of 20 ppm, Cresol Red (CR), Methylene Green (MG), Malachite Green Oxalate (MGO), Methylene Blue (MB), Alizarin Red (AR), Congo Red (CR), and Methyl Orange (MO), respectively (Figure S11).

elements.content: Obviously, the concentrations of the solution have fallen, resulting in the solution colors of MB and CR with 2 changing from blue to light blue and from red to pale red (). The solution color of MB with 3 also almost faded away after 240 min, and the PXRD results of the samples of complexes 2 and 3 can maintain their crystalline structures after the dye adsorption in the two aqueous solutions (Figure S12). However, it is also found that the colors of other solutions did not change before and after the dye adsorption experiments. As a result, it can be inferred that the polarized −COOH groups within the pore surfaces of MOFs may also play important role in the adsorption process, because of the electrostatic interactions between the frameworks and MB/CR molecules. The proper size of the dye molecules and channels of the frameworks may be responsible for these results above. Herein, the sizes of the two dye molecules are ∼20.2 Å × 10.1 Å × 10.2 Å for CR and ∼14.8 Å × 5.0 Å × 4.2 Å for MB, respectively. For the 1D open channels of the frameworks, if the sizes of the dye molecules in two orientations are matched well with the size of the channel, they will be captured easily. It is obvious that MB has suitable size compared to 2 and 3. Because the dye remains unfixed, others may pass through the channels easily. Meanwhile, the CR molecules may be a more appropriate size for the channels of complex 2 compared with 3.

elements.content: The quantity of the adsorbed dye at equilibrium was computed using the following formula: Q eq = (C 0 – C eq)V/m; where Q eq is the amount of dye molecules adsorbed by the targeted sample (expressed in units of mmol g–1); C 0 is the initial concentration of the dye molecules (mmol L–1); C eq is the concentration of dye molecules (mmol L–1) when the adsorption process reaches equilibrium; V is the volume of the dye solution (L), and m is the mass of crystals that we soaked (g). By calculation, the values of Q eq for 2 adsorbed MB and CR are 0.0091 and 0.0087 mmol g–1, and the values of Q eq for 3 adsorbed MB are 0.0079 mmol g–1 (a), respectively.

elements.content: Compared with dye adsorption, the dye selectivity may be more attractive and challenging. To verify whether the crystals possess the ability to separate dye molecules, it is usual to choose one dye to be adsorbed and another dye to be unabsorbed left. Here, the samples of 2 are used to attempt to separate MB and CR molecules. Because the adsorption rate of MB is similar to the rate of CR, when soaking the samples (20 mg) in 10 mL of the aqueous solution containing an equal mixture of MB and CR (20 ppm), the absorption peaks of CR obviously decreased and only exhibited the characteristic peaks of MB (b). These phenomena imply that complex 2 not only can adsorb CR or MB, but also has the ability to separate their mixture.

elements.content: In summary, three new 3D porous MOFs have been yielded successfully via a symmetrical rigid H3L ligand in this work. Complex 1 is a twofold interpenetrating 3D network possessing the [Zn4O­(COO)6] SBUs, and complexes 2 and 3 are two 3D isostructural nets including different N-donor tectons and partly deprotonated HL2– ligands. The gas adsorption experiments indicated that three complexes have high uptake and selectivity for CO2. More significantly, complexes 2 and 3 also have the excellent selection and adsorption capacity of the CR and MB dyes. These results may provide an insight into the development of new functional MOF materials with potential applications in gas adsorption and dye separation.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, three new 3D porous MOFs have been yielded successfully via a symmetrical rigid H3L ligand in this work. Complex 1 is a twofold interpenetrating 3D network possessing the [Zn4O(COO)6] SBUs, and complexes 2 and 3 are two 3D isostructural nets including different N-donor tectons and partly deprotonated HL2- ligands. The gas adsorption experiments indicated that three complexes have high uptake and selectivity for CO2. More significantly, complexes 2 and 3 also have the excellent selection and adsorption capacity of the CR and MB dyes. These results may provide an insight into the development of new functional MOF materials with potential applications in gas adsorption and dye separation.

A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0297 g, 0.1 mmol), H3L (0.0181 g, 0.05 mmol), and NMP/H2O (16.0 mL v/v: 3/1) (NMP = N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and then heated at 145 °C for 72 h. After a gradual cooling procedure to room temperature, the block crystals were obtained in ∼54.0% yield (based on Zn). Anal. Calcd for C62 H65Zn4N4O21: C, 50.87; H, 4.44; N, 3.83. Found: C, 50.53; H, 4.17; N, 3.72%. IR (cm–1, Figure S1): 3438 (m), 2917 (m), 1604 (s), 1509 (s), 1400 (s), 1313 (s), 1108 (s), 858 (w), 781 (s) 744 (m), 543 (m), 472 (s).

A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0297 g, 0.1 mmol), H3L (0.0181 g, 0.05 mmol), bpe (0.0091 g, 0.05 mmol) DMF/H2O (18.0 mL, v/v: 1/1) (DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide) was mixed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25 mL), and then heated at 145 °C for 72 h. After a gradual cooling procedure to room temperature, block crystals were obtained in ∼53.0% yield (based on Zn). Anal. Calcd for C28H22ZnN2O8: C, 57.99; H, 3.82; N, 4.83. Found: C, 57.53; H, 3.17; N, 4.30%. IR (cm–1, Figure S1): 3451 (m), 3058 (w), 2940 (m), 2665 (m), 2538 (m), 1689 (s), 1614 (s), 1535 (s), 1411 (s), 1280 (m), 1180 (m), 1093 (m), 863 (m), 779 (s).

Synthesis of [Zn­(HL)­(bipy)<sub>0.5</sub>]·DMF·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

The procedure was similar to the preparation of 2, except that bpe was replaced by bipy. The block crystals were obtained in ∼51.0% yield (based on Zn). Anal. cln_elements.content:
In complex 1, the three carboxylate groups of the fully deprotonated L3– ligands adopt the bridging bidentate (η2μ2χ2) fashion to connect the Zn­(II) ions (a). Interestingly, like that of MOF-5, a [Zn4O­(COO)6] SBU is formed by six carboxylate groups from six different L3– ligands, two coordinated NMP molecules, and one coordinated water molecule (a); however, the solvent molecules are not included in the SBU of MOF-5. The rigid terphenyl tectons as the spacers link the [Zn4O­(COO)6] SBUs to form a 3D porous framework (b) with 1D channels along a axis with the effective aperture sizes of 13.7 × 14.8 Å2 (b,c). Due to the large voids, the two single 3D networks are further entangled with each other to result in a twofold interpenetrating motif. When the [Zn4O­(COO)6] SBUs are regarded as 6-connected nodes and all L3– ligands act as 3-connected linkers. The whole structure can thus be represented as a (3,6)-c sit network with a symbol of (4·62)2(42·610·83), as shown in d. The calculated void volume is 26.6% of the total crystal volume by using the PLATON program after excluding NMP and H2O molecules.

Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD) and Thermal Analysis

PXRD shows that the peak positions of the obtained crystalline samples of complexes 1–3 match well with the ones simulated from the single-crystal data, manifesting the high phase purity of the synthesized samples (Figure S4). The TGA of 1–3 was performed under a N2 atmosphere from 30 to 700 °C (Figure S5), which showed that complex 1 indicated a weight loss of 30.8% in the range of 30–260 °C, ascribed to the release of four NMP molecule and three H2O molecule per formula unit (calcd 31.2%). Complex 2 released one DMF molecule and one H2O molecule between 30 and 308 °C with a weight loss of 15.5% (calcd 15.7%). For 3, it is similar to that of 2, and it lost one lattice water and one DMF molecule from 30 to 306 °C with a weight loss of 15.1% (calcd 15.5%), the major framework then began to collapse.

Gas Adsorption Behavior

To obtain the guest-free phase of 1a–3a, the samples of complexes 1a–3a were soaked in CH3Cl for 3 days, and then heated under vacuum for 6 h (at 160 °C for 1; 2 and 3 at 120 °C) to exclude the guest molecules, which is evidenced by the TGA curves (Figure S5). In order to study the nature of the pores and gas adsorption properties of 1a–3a, the isotherms are measured for N2, CH4, and CO2, respectively. The N2 adsorption isotherms of the activated samples of 1a–3a are measured at 77 K (Figure S6). The reversible N2 sorption experiments of 1a–3a at 77 K all showed the type II adsorption isotherm behaviors, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas are 10.7, 16.5, and 15.4 m2 g–1, respectively.

Moreover, the CO2 sorption properties of the desolvated 1a–3a at three different temperatures (195, 273, and 298 K) were also studied carefully. At 195 K, their CO2 isotherms show almost identical adsorption performance (). The CO2 uptake values are 66.1 cm3 g–1 (12.9 wt %), 70.4 cm3 g–1 (13.9 wt %), and 58.7 cm3 g–1 (11.5 wt %), respectively. However, once the measure temperatures changed to 273 and 298 K, the interesting results were observed (Figure S7). For 1a, the CO2 uptake are 20.2 ccm3 g–1 (3.97 wt %) at 273 K and 11.4 cm3 g–1 (2.24 wt %) at 298 K and 1 bar. For 2a, its CO2 isotherms are close to linear and the CO2 uptake values are 28.1 cm3 g–1 (5.12 wt %) at 273 K and 13.1 cm3 g–1 (2.57 wt %) at 298 K at 1 bar. For 3a, its CO2 isotherms are also type I adsorption isotherms and the CO2 uptake values are 17.7 cm3 g–1 (3.48 wt %) and 13.4 cm3 g–1 (2.63 wt %) at 273 and 298 K, respectively. It is obvious that the final CO2 uptake value of 2a at ambient temperature is comparable with those of 1a and 3a, while the uptake of 2a is relatively higher at 273 K than those of 1a and 3a. This may be, on one hand, attributed to the single network and uncoordinated carboxylate O atoms (inserted into the surface of the pores) relative to 2a, which make the framework highly polar and form stronger affinity with CO2; and on the other hand, it is ascribed to the larger effective free void of 2a (26.6% for 1a, 28.3% for 2a, and 25.1% for 3a). In addition, all of them do not adsorb CH4 well at different temperatures.
cln_elements.clean_text:
In complex 1, the three carboxylate groups of the fully deprotonated L3- ligands adopt the bridging bidentate (η2μ2χ2) fashion to connect the Zn(II) ions (a). Interestingly, like that of MOF-5, a [Zn4O(COO)6] SBU is formed by six carboxylate groups from six different L3- ligands, two coordinated NMP molecules, and one coordinated water molecule (a); however, the solvent molecules are not included in the SBU of MOF-5. The rigid terphenyl tectons as the spacers link the [Zn4O(COO)6] SBUs to form a 3D porous framework (b) with 1D channels along a axis with the effective aperture sizes of 13.7 × 14.8 Å2 (b,c). Due to the large voids, the two single 3D networks are further entangled with each other to result in a twofold interpenetrating motif. When the [Zn4O(COO)6] SBUs are regarded as 6-connected nodes and all L3- ligands act as 3-connected linkers. The whole structure can thus be represented as a (3,6)-c  sit  network with a symbol of (4⋅62)2(42⋅610⋅83), as shown in d. The calculated void volume is 26.6% of the total crystal volume by using the PLATON program after excluding NMP and H2O molecules.

Complex 2 released one DMF molecule and one H2O molecule between 30 and 308 °C with a weight loss of 15.5% (calcd 15.7%). For 3, it is similar to that of 2, and it lost one lattice water and one DMF molecule from 30 to 306 °C with a weight loss of 15.1% (calcd 15.5%), the major framework then began to collapse.
